Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Build extensions targets file for build pipelines" (#7770) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Progress on https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/2883

This adds an optional point to insert targets file during the build.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Use Json.Encode to avoid js injection" (#7801) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
All required documentation is on the following issue:

Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/2911

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "No documentation on publishing "Documentation" content/URL from the API" (#7800) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug
Ability to upload README content from the API is missing from the documentation ?

### To Reproduce
I can manually upload a version-specific documentation :
1. Go to the "Manage" page of a package
2. Unfold the "Documentation" part
3. Put raw content or a Github link, or upload from a local file

### Expected behavior
We should be able to upload at the same time we publish a package. I suspect (hope?) it's possible, but searching  the following documentations yielded nothing:
 - https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/api/package-publish-resource
 - https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/api/registration-base-url-resource
 - https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/api/nuget-protocols

I also tried by spying quickly to what is being done when manually uploading  with Devtools, but I could not yield anything really actionable API-wise.

### Additional context
We are building and publishing from CI, so manually uploading is really not an option. I have seen there is expected work to make the NuGet self-contained including the README/documentation part, but so far this work has not yet started.

So, is it possible or not to perform this documentation upload step from the API ?

I'm quite a newbie in regards of the NuGet world, so it's possible I am missing something obvious here. Please direct me to the proper resources if they exists !

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Upgrade telemetry" (#7788) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Consume NuGet.Jobs and ServerCommon updates for telemetry and heartbeats.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Functional test script update to wait for the service to start up after the deployment" (#7799) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Progress on https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/2863

App service deployment reports success way before the service initialization completes successfully and is able to serve requests. This breaks our tests that encounter 502 responses and fail.
This change adds a delay and a response test to the test run script to make sure we run tests against the working service.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "HTTP to HTTPS redirect differences between App and Cloud services" (#7798) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Progress on https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/2863

Cloud and app services handle the HTTP to HTTPS redirect differently (we can enable "Always HTTPS" for an app service, while we can't do that for the cloud service), so the test update is required to accommodate for that difference.
This change also requires the test configuration to be updated.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Merge branch 'dev' to master" (#7797) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "NuGet.exe restore E2E tests should be run in all entry points (msbuild, whenever dotnet.exe if possible)" (#9037) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Commandline integration tests in https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/test/NuGet.Clients.Tests/NuGet.CommandLine.Test/RestoreNETCoreTest.cs cover the majority of the restore functionality tests. 
The NuGet.exe/MSBuild restore functionality used to be consistent, and now there's plenty of diverging code (specifically, the dg spec generation). 

In general we should ensure that scenario tests like these are run cross client :)

Special scenarios
NuGet/Home#5855
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/3109#discussion_r364023545

cc @jeffkl

```
F:\VSExtensibility [develop ≡]>      
```

This is inconsistent because of https://github.com/microsoft/msbuild/blob/8d37fbb97003e96516a2054e51dd5fabfd720ed6/src/MSBuild/XMake.cs#L1356. 

The restore target is special cased. 

Ideally all of the NuGet tooling is consistent. 

The argument for ignoring missing imports is summarized in https://github.com/microsoft/msbuild/pull/3278. 

```
Some shipped SDKs have imports that are property based but are missing conditions. This makes it impossible to retrofit them with a NuGet package since NuGet restore won't succeed because an import is missing.
```

On the flip side, what if the imports in question might actually be genuinely missing cause of a setup issue. They might need to bring in a PackageReference themselves. 

Regardless of what the decision is, all NuGet tooling should be consistent. 

Related https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7576

fyi @jeffkl @zivkan 

Thoughts @NuGet/nuget-client?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet pack --ouput directory no longer relative to current directory" (#9034) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @frankkilcommins on Tuesday, November 12, 2019 10:30:50 AM_

As of yesterday, I get issues with dotnet pack where the output directory was created at the root working directory rather than relative to the current directory. This caused subsequent pack command to fail as the expected pattern was no longer matching.

sdk version: 2.1.500

Output:
`[command]C:\hostedtoolcache\windows\dncs\2.1.500\x64\dotnet.exe pack d:\a\1\s\DUPSCore\DigitalUserProvisioningService.Data.Core\DigitalUserProvisioningService.Data.Core.csproj --configuration release --version-suffix 96713 --output nupkgs
Microsoft (R) Build Engine version 16.3.0+0f4c62fea for .NET Core
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.`

Package was created in the following directory:
`Successfully created package 'd:\a\1\s\nupkgs\DigitalUserProvisioningService.Data.Core.1.3.0-ci-96713.nupkg'.`

Expected directory:
`d:\a\1\s\DUPSCore\DigitalUserProvisioningService.Data.Core\nupkgs\DigitalUserProvisioningService.Data.Core.1.3.0-ci-96713.nupkg`

I've worked around the issue by prefixing the _current_ directory to the `output` command:
`--configuration $(BuildConfiguration) --version-suffix $(Build.BuildId) --output DUPSCore/DigitalUserProvisioningService.Data.Core/nupkgs`

Just wondering why/when this changed and can I expect my builds to break again if/when it's reverted or resolved.


_Copied from original issue: dotnet/sdk#3894_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet add package --source not imperative" (#9033) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @iamalexmang on Tuesday, January 7, 2020 10:52:50 AM_

I strongly believe that if I explicitly mention a --source parameter for the package, especially in the format of a file system path, the CLI should not try validate the package's existence on any other sources. 
As of right now, when I specify the source parameter as a FS path, if either of the sources specified at the solution level, user global level (in %AppData%/NuGet) or computer level (Program Files (x86)), are unauthenticated, the package installation will fail. Regretfully, the error is completely unspecific as it complains which source returns a 401 Unauthorized error, though the package exists on the file system at the specified location.

_Copied from original issue: dotnet/sdk#4137_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Make install VSIX script resilient to incomplete VS installs" (#9032) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
A number of CI builds fail when VS is in a broken installation state, requiring someone to log in to the CI machine and repair the VS install. This can be reproduced at will by killing vsixinstaller.exe in the middle of an installation (for example, canceling the CI build while it's installing the VSIX).

VS install team informed us we can use the "resume" command on vs_installer.exe to have it repair/resume the install.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "How to upgrade local repository from .net core 2.2 to .net core 3.*?" (#8922) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I have local nuget repository wich contains over 800 packages. Version of .net core is 2.2.
I have script that can push existing packages into this repo. Packages must be at my local computer.

So, how can i download all .net core 3.* sdk packages to my computer? If so, i can easy push all of this packages into my local repository.

Thank you!
